Data on other population subcategories also come from the UN World Population Prospects (2015), rescaled when necessary to match the source data.

simpledes: Number of individuals in a group.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The population looked at is comprised of male individuals only.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/top-incomes-in-korea-update-1933-2016-wid-world-working-paper-2018-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon(2018), Top Incomes in Korea: Update, 1933-2016, WID.world Working Paper 2018/12[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/wid_working_paper_2014_2_korea/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon and Jongil Kim (2014), Top Incomes in Korea: Evidence from Income Tax Statistics, WID.world Working Paper 2014/2.[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]https://esa.un.org/unpd/wpp/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN World Population Prospects (2015).[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: From 1911 to 2017 we the use data provided by the WID researchers for total and adult population (see source). We extend it to the other years using growth rates from the UN World Population Prospects (2015). Data on other population subcategories also come from the UN World Population Prospects (2015), rescaled when necessary to match the source data.

simpledes: Number of adults as tax units.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Kim, Nak Nyeon and Kim, Jongil (2014). Top Incomes in Korea, 1933-2010. Evidence from Income Tax Statistics. WTID Working Paper 2014/2.;
method: Individuals aged 20+. Statistics are for all Korea (North and South combined) before liberation in 1945, and for South Korea after liberation.

simpledes: Number of tax units among the tax population.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Kim, Nak Nyeon and Kim, Jongil (2014). Top Incomes in Korea, 1933-2010. Evidence from Income Tax Statistics. WTID Working Paper 2014/2.;
method: Individuals aged 20+. Statistics are for all Korea (North and South combined) before liberation in 1945, and for South Korea after liberation.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/top-incomes-in-korea-update-1933-2016-wid-world-working-paper-2018-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon(2018), Top Incomes in Korea: Update, 1933-2016, WID.world Working Paper 2018/12[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/wid_working_paper_2014_2_korea/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon and Jongil Kim (2014), Top Incomes in Korea: Evidence from Income Tax Statistics, WID.world Working Paper 2014/2.[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Statistics cover all Korea (North and South combined) before liberation in 1945, and South Korea only after liberation. The unit of the amounts in the colonial period is Yen. To convert into the current KRW the amount should be multiplied by 1/1000.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/wealth-inequality-in-korea-2000-2013-journal-of-the-korean-welfare-state-and-social-policy-2018/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kim, Nak Nyeon(2018), Wealth Inequality in Korea, 2000-2013: Evidence from Inheritance Tax Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: The inheritance tax data for 2008-2009 was not used here because of inconsistency of figures in the data. The amount of net personal wealth estimated here is much less than the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets. The difference could be explained as follows. First, the net household wealth in the National Balance Sheets includes the asset of non-profit sector. Second, the estimate of net personal wealth covers only real estate and financial assets, while other kinds of assets are included in the National Balance Sheets. Third, while the real estates in the National Balance Sheets are those in market prices, they are in government appraisal values, lower than market prices. Considering the share of real estate in the net household wealth is 76% (the average in 2000-2013)  and the total amount in government appraisal values is 67% of that in market prices, the net household wealth would be underestimated as much as 25% at least from the difference in government appraisal values and market prices of real estate.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: WID.world computations using fiscal and net national income.
method: Fiscal income rescaled to match the macroeconomic aggregates.

shortname: Net Public Wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Net Public Wealth to Net National Income Ratio is the division of net wealth of the public sector by net national income.
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Net Personal Wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Net Personal Wealth to Net National Income Ratio is the division of net wealth of the personal sector (households) by net national income.
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Net national wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Wealth-Income Ratio is the division of national wealth by national income.
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: Net Private Wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Net Private Wealth to Net National Income Ratio is the division of net private wealth by net national income. Private wealth consists of net wealth of the personal sector (households) and the non-profit sector (philanthropy foundations, religious organizations, universities, etc.).
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

shortname: PPP conversion factor, LCU per EUR
simpledes: PPP conversion factor of curent local currency to current PPP EUR.
longtype: Exchange rate series
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=PPP2011[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: We extrapolate the PPP from the latest ICP (2017) using the evolution of the price index relative to the reference country.
